text1: Compulsory vaccinations would reduce the prevalence of diseases.
text2: Better hygiene and sanitation has caused the decline of diseases, not vaccines.

text1: Compulsory vaccinations would reduce the prevalence of diseases.
text2: Vaccines do not make the virus extinct. To do that the geographical source of said virus should be located and sanitized fully, which is close to impossible.

text1: Mandatory vaccination is needed in order to maintain herd immunity, protecting those individuals who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons.
text2: The 'herd immunity' concept only applies to contagious diseases, i.e. not to vaccine-preventable diseases such as tetanus.

text1: Mandatory vaccination is needed in order to maintain herd immunity, protecting those individuals who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons.
text2: High vaccination levels are attained in many countries through information and public engagement campaigns, WHO, and a study commissioned by the EU even found no link between vaccinations being compulsory and vaccination rates. This suggests that making vaccination mandatory is not strictly needed to achieve herd immunity.

text1: Mandatory vaccination is needed in order to maintain herd immunity, protecting those individuals who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons.
text2: Herd immunity might not be attainable even if vaccines are mandated due to intrinsic levels of vaccine non-response (i.e. failed immunisation).

text1: Mandatory vaccination is needed in order to maintain herd immunity, protecting those individuals who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons.
text2: Mandatory vaccination of others, for specific disease(s), is not a viable management method for immune-suppressed individuals.

text1: Many elderly people will be able to avoid sickness.
text2: Elderly people who have adequately vaccinated themselves will not be exposed to any undue risk due to the choice of others preferring not to vaccinate themselves.

text1: Many vaccines are less effective in the elderly, so they may be less effective despite following all the recommendations. Thus they rely on herd immunity from others being vaccinated.
text2: Elderly people who have adequately vaccinated themselves will not be exposed to any undue risk due to the choice of others preferring not to vaccinate themselves.

text1: More research needs to be done on vaccines for the elderly. A study indicates that evidence for protection in adults aged 65 years or older is lacking.
text2: Elderly people who have adequately vaccinated themselves will not be exposed to any undue risk due to the choice of others preferring not to vaccinate themselves.

text1: The above linked source emphasizes that young and healthy people have higher rates of response to the flu shot. Herd immunity cannot be attained by only vaccinating those with compromised immune systems like the elderly. The failure rate in the elderly is the reason for encouraging vaccination in the young healthy population.
text2: An example of vaccine that does not fully protect against the disease is that against flu, which only cuts the risk of hospitalisation by 30-70% elderly people (not in care homes). This is in part because of the genetic variations in the virus.

text1: The link in the above claim describes the "largest measles epidemic in North America in the last decade" as consisting of 725 cases. This is an excellent example of the effectiveness of herd immunity achieved through widespread vaccination.
text2: Even in areas with 97% vaccination rates, outbreaks occur.

text1: Failed immunisation is exactly why mass immunization is required to improve protection. If we can reduce the number of vectors (in this case infected people and all the stuff they come in contact with) then we can reduce the number of infections.
text2: Herd immunity might not be attainable even if vaccines are mandated due to intrinsic levels of vaccine non-response (i.e. failed immunisation).

text1: Herd immunity is the slowing or prevention of the spread of disease, due to a prevalence of immunity in a population. It is not an all-or-nothing marker to be "attained." Thus vaccines that give partial immunity can still save lives, on a population basis.
text2: Herd immunity might not be attainable even if vaccines are mandated due to intrinsic levels of vaccine non-response (i.e. failed immunisation).

text1: Many children died before a vaccine for any virus was made available.
text2: It is unlikely that people who oppose vaccination would be okay with vaccination being mandatory.

text1: Cases of paralytic polio in the US fell from 15,000 annually in 1955 (when the first vaccine was introduced) to 10 per year in the 1970s.
text2: Better hygiene and sanitation has caused the decline of diseases, not vaccines.

text1: The primary thesis refers to "worldwide" vaccinations. The above source reports the decline in disease mainly in the US, where sanitation/nutrition have improved greatly over the last century. It would be wrong to argue against vaccinating worldwide, just because first-world countries have lower death rates due to their higher standard of living.
text2: Better hygiene and sanitation has caused the decline of diseases, not vaccines.

text1: Both factors (vaccines and sanitation/nutrition) can contribute to decreases in case-rates and death rates. The effect of improving living conditions, is not an argument against using vaccines as well.
text2: Better hygiene and sanitation has caused the decline of diseases, not vaccines.

text1: Improved standard of living has had a much greater impact on death rate, than on the incidence of disease. The case rate (incidence) has been greatly impacted by effective vaccine for measles.
text2: Better hygiene and sanitation has caused the decline of diseases, not vaccines.

text1: This is not about complete extermination, but rather a reduction of illness.
text2: Vaccines do not make the virus extinct. To do that the geographical source of said virus should be located and sanitized fully, which is close to impossible.

text1: Disease control by the combined methods of vaccinations and eradication of the source of the sickness (killing mosquitoes, draining marshes, eradicating rats etc.) has proven highly successful in the past
text2: Vaccines do not make the virus extinct. To do that the geographical source of said virus should be located and sanitized fully, which is close to impossible.

text1: Disease control by the combined methods of vaccinations and eradication of the source of the sickness (killing mosquitoes, draining marshes, eradicating rats etc.) has proven highly successful in the past
text2: This is difficult to execute inpoorer countries with un(der)developed infrastructure and lack of resources

text1: Viruses can become extinct if there is widespread vaccination, AND there is no non-human host or reservoir for the virus. This happened for smallpox, and there's the potential for it to happen with measles and polio in our lifetimes (depending on your age now).
text2: Vaccines do not make the virus extinct. To do that the geographical source of said virus should be located and sanitized fully, which is close to impossible.

text1: Viruses can become extinct if there is widespread vaccination, AND there is no non-human host or reservoir for the virus. This happened for smallpox, and there's the potential for it to happen with measles and polio in our lifetimes (depending on your age now).
text2: When there's an animal or other reservoir (i.e. rabies, which is carried by animals; or the plague, carried by rats; or tetanus, which has spores that can live in soil) the disease can't be eradicated solely by vaccinating humans.

text1: In a civilized society, the needs of the many should, at times when the impact is greatest, be above the needs of the few or individual. Eradicating or limiting a disease by use of vaccinations is for the greater good of society.
text2: Due to the scarcity of resources, seeking to eradicate any one disease might come at a loss to society. This would be the case if the ratio of benefits to cost for such mandatory immunisation campaign were lower than that for alternative measures that benefit public health.

text1: In a civilized society, the needs of the many should, at times when the impact is greatest, be above the needs of the few or individual. Eradicating or limiting a disease by use of vaccinations is for the greater good of society.
text2: It is the means of a 'few' immuno-compromised individuals that we are protecting. So our rights to bodily choice is affected by the few. Some immuno-compromised are still vaccinated. Only those who have anaphylaxis are fully exempt.

text1: In a civilized society, the needs of the many should, at times when the impact is greatest, be above the needs of the few or individual. Eradicating or limiting a disease by use of vaccinations is for the greater good of society.
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: There's a price to pay for living in a civilized society. You sacrifice certain individual freedoms for the benefits of teamwork and being in a social group. In this case, the sacrifice is only the freedom to be ignorant, which is not a high value form of individual liberty.
text2: "Ignorance" is not the freedom at stake here. It is the freedom of deciding what goes into your body. Ignorance simply means not knowing.

text1: Eradicating certain communicable, vaccine-preventable diseases (like polio & measles) worldwide requires that developed countries continue to maintain high rates of vaccination and immunity, even though individuals in those countries are at low risk of exposure to the disease.
text2: Eradication of any diseases is an arbitrary target that hasn't been agreed democratically.

text1: Eradicating certain communicable, vaccine-preventable diseases (like polio & measles) worldwide requires that developed countries continue to maintain high rates of vaccination and immunity, even though individuals in those countries are at low risk of exposure to the disease.
text2: Eradication of other non-contagious diseases such as tetanus cannot be attained via vaccination, since no herd immunity can be attained in this way.

text1: The erasure of human pain and suffering doesn't need political backing to be morally just.
text2: Eradication of any diseases is an arbitrary target that hasn't been agreed democratically.

text1: The erasure of human pain and suffering doesn't need political backing to be morally just.
text2: It requires investing a lot of tax money so it does requires political backing.

text1: Seeking to eradicate one disease may strengthen healthcare infrastructure, as the Global Polio Eradication Initiative has done in developing countries. The resources poured into eradicating one disease, have resulted in improved access to healthcare for many conditions. (p. 2)
text2: Due to the scarcity of resources, seeking to eradicate any one disease might come at a loss to society. This would be the case if the ratio of benefits to cost for such mandatory immunisation campaign were lower than that for alternative measures that benefit public health.

text1: Strategies to eliminate certain diseases completely (like smallpox, polio and measles) may free up future resources, by saving the money that is currently spent annually on the burden of disease.
text2: Due to the scarcity of resources, seeking to eradicate any one disease might come at a loss to society. This would be the case if the ratio of benefits to cost for such mandatory immunisation campaign were lower than that for alternative measures that benefit public health.

text1: Immunocompromised people should not receive live vaccine, out of the concern that it will cause active diseases. They can still receive killed/inactivated vaccines, but are less likely to respond and gain immunity from them, because that's what immunocompromised means.
text2: It is the means of a 'few' immuno-compromised individuals that we are protecting. So our rights to bodily choice is affected by the few. Some immuno-compromised are still vaccinated. Only those who have anaphylaxis are fully exempt.

text1: Small pox has been eradicated primarily through a successful global vaccination program.WHO
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: Polio is very close to being eradicated by vaccines.
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: The aim of vaccines is to reduce the amount of a virus in circulation in society and thus reduce the amount of infection from that disease, not necessarily eradicate them.
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: Vaccinations reduce the need to treat diseases with antibiotics, lowering the chances of antibiotic resistance mutations.
text2: Although reduction of drug-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae (DRSP) by pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCVs) has recently become a reality, Serotype 19A, which is both antibiotic resistant and a common cause of disease, is not affected by PCV7 and is now increasing worldwide. One of the recommended strategies to deal with this increase is the 'limitation of antibiotic use.'

text1: For strains of strep that have been reduced by effective vaccine, there has been great reduction in the need for antibiotics. Further reduction in the need for antibiotics can be achieved by developing vaccines to strains that were not included in previous vaccines.
text2: Although reduction of drug-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae (DRSP) by pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCVs) has recently become a reality, Serotype 19A, which is both antibiotic resistant and a common cause of disease, is not affected by PCV7 and is now increasing worldwide. One of the recommended strategies to deal with this increase is the 'limitation of antibiotic use.'

text1: Mandating childhood vaccines ensure that parents choices do not compromise child well-being later in life.
text2: It is unwise to trust governments and pharmaceutical companies over parents.

text1: Vaccines are ultimately designed, administered and approved of by medical professionals and are, as such, subject to high levels of review.
text2: It is unwise to trust governments and pharmaceutical companies over parents.

text1: Parents often have little to no knowledge about the impact and outcome of vaccination.
text2: It is unwise to trust governments and pharmaceutical companies over parents.

text1: Parents are more invested in their individual child's well being than the community perspective.
text2: It is unwise to trust governments and pharmaceutical companies over parents.

text1: There's a famous example which solves your doubt: car manufacturers get money from seat belts, but no one says that we shouldn't use them. Equally, if a pharmaceutical company gets money from vaccines, we shouldn't say that there's an ethical conflict.
text2: Pharmaceutical companies thrive when people are sick. This creates a strong ethical conflict, which needs to be addressed.

text1: There's a famous example which solves your doubt: car manufacturers get money from seat belts, but no one says that we shouldn't use them. Equally, if a pharmaceutical company gets money from vaccines, we shouldn't say that there's an ethical conflict.
text2: This is not a good analogy, because there is no evidence that car manufacturers make money from people being injured in vehicular accidents. The parent pro alleges that pharmaceutical companies profit by selling drugs to treat illnesses, thus giving them less incentive to prevent illness.

text1: (Even assuming that pharma companies have no internal ethics...) the FDA requires proof of efficacy, and an acceptable side effect profile, for any product to make it on the market, and there is competition between companies to demonstrate the best results. If vaccines are mandatory, there will still be competition between companies to demonstrate the best vaccines, with the least side effects, in order to gain market share, and this competition will benefit consumers/ patients.
text2: Pharmaceutical companies thrive when people are sick. This creates a strong ethical conflict, which needs to be addressed.

text1: Past corruption cases do not suggest that they can never be avoided.
text2: Past cases of corruption from 'Big Pharma' companies bribery [1] [2] remind us that the risk that this will happen again can never be fully avoided.

text1: All public vaccinations have to be approved by an independent committee regulated by law. This reduces the risk of corruption from pharmaceutical companies.
text2: Mandatory vaccinations open us (completely) up to the potential corruption of pharmaceutical companies.

text1: All public vaccinations have to be approved by an independent committee regulated by law. This reduces the risk of corruption from pharmaceutical companies.
text2: Unless the committee itself has conflicts of interest or becomes simply corrupt.

text1: All public vaccinations have to be approved by an independent committee regulated by law. This reduces the risk of corruption from pharmaceutical companies.
text2: Mandatory vaccinations would mean we have to use every vaccine produced on the basis of risk/reward or 'minimal' side effects. For any such treatment you would need a 0 risk treatment, such a thing does not exist.

text1: Whatever the side effects and business interests - a drug that keeps diseases like measles or smallpox extinct is worth all risks.
text2: Mandatory vaccinations open us (completely) up to the potential corruption of pharmaceutical companies.

text1: A solution for this would be to nationalize the pharmaceutical industry.
text2: Mandatory vaccinations open us (completely) up to the potential corruption of pharmaceutical companies.

text1: A solution for this would be to nationalize the pharmaceutical industry.
text2: The race to cash in on new cures and treatments means that these companies do invest huge amounts of money into medical research and development. A nationalized pharmaceutical invest less into research and would likely have limited funding slowing down the advancements which could otherwise be made.

text1: A solution for this would be to nationalize the pharmaceutical industry.
text2: Governments are not immune to corruption. If the government running the nationalized pharmaceutical industry was itself corrupt there would be very little recourse available to the citizens.

text1: A solution for this would be to nationalize the pharmaceutical industry.
text2: If it is necessary to nationalize the pharmaceutical industry before mandatory vaccination can be implemented, then we are not [yet] ready for mandatory vaccination.

text1: Making anything mandatory (like seat belts in cars, or carrying car insurance in order to drive) may create a potential for abuse by the companies who produce the mandatory product. This risk can be balanced by competition within the market of producers, or by government regulation of the industry.
text2: Mandatory vaccinations open us (completely) up to the potential corruption of pharmaceutical companies.

text1: Making vaccination mandatory actually creates incentives for pharmaceutical companies to jump in and create cheaper and better vaccine as you do not have the risk of creating product which will not be used. E.g. check the price list of CDC www.cdc.gov
text2: Mandatory vaccinations open us (completely) up to the potential corruption of pharmaceutical companies.

text1: Studies proving efficacy have established certain protocols for transport, storage and administration of vaccines; the vaccine is only proven to be effective when those procedures are followed. A failure to maintain these protocols should not be an argument against efficacy; it should only reinforce the importance of proper storage.
text2: Vaccines may become ineffective as a consequence of mishandling of the vaccine between the production and delivery site, for instance due to failure in the cold chain.

text1: Recommendations have been tailored over time to account for many things. Changing recommendations should not lead anyone to "throw the baby out with the bath water" by concluding that vaccines are not beneficial at all.
text2: Scientific studies are indicating that vaccine-induced immunity wanes over time. Each disease is different in how long immunity lasts. ACIP keeps recommending more and more vaccines and doses as a work-around for waning vaccines.

text1: Small pox has been eradicated primarily through a successful global vaccination program.WHO
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: Polio is very close to being eradicated by vaccines.
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: The aim of vaccines is to reduce the amount of a virus in circulation in society and thus reduce the amount of infection from that disease, not necessarily eradicate them.
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: More than a dozen major infectious diseases have been controlled in many parts of the world by vaccines.
text2: Vaccines are not sufficiently effective to justify making them mandatory.

text1: More than a dozen major infectious diseases have been controlled in many parts of the world by vaccines.
text2: We are therefore in an ever increasing requirement to vaccinate because it can only be controlled and not eradicated. The effect of multiple vaccinations is not well studied.

text1: There are many well-designed, placebo-controlled and double blinded studies which prove efficacy of several vaccines.
text2: Vaccines are not sufficiently effective to justify making them mandatory.

text1: Vaccines not being fully effective doesn't mean we shouldn't vaccinate.
text2: Vaccines are not sufficiently effective to justify making them mandatory.

text1: Vaccines are among the most effective of any treatments modern medicine provides, such as chemotherapy. If you use any modern medicine for any situation, refusing vaccines should be understood be irrational.
text2: Vaccines are not sufficiently effective to justify making them mandatory.

text1: Officials 'assault' people who put others at risk on a routine basis, such as police arresting criminals. Mandatory medication, when someone poses a threat of harm, is legitimate, such as medically treating violent psychosis.
text2: Pushing a needle into a person without their consent constitutes assault.

text1: The legal definition of assault involves harm or unwanted physical contact. Thus consent is critical: many medical procedures (such as cutting someone open and removing their appendix) in the absence of consent, would constitute assault.
text2: Pushing a needle into a person without their consent constitutes assault.

text1: A lack of vaccination puts "weaker individuals" (immune deficient, and children too young to get vaccinated yet) at risk and can lead to their infection. Those who know that they suffer from a transmittable disease that can gravely endanger the lives of weaker individuals, and still refuse to be vaccinated, could be classified as assaulting those who are vulnerable.
text2: Pushing a needle into a person without their consent constitutes assault.

text1: A lack of vaccination puts "weaker individuals" (immune deficient, and children too young to get vaccinated yet) at risk and can lead to their infection. Those who know that they suffer from a transmittable disease that can gravely endanger the lives of weaker individuals, and still refuse to be vaccinated, could be classified as assaulting those who are vulnerable.
text2: Assault in many developed nations and U.S. States are based on knowingly and intentionally performing an unconsentual action on someone. Someone who unknowingly or unintentionally spread a disease couldn't be held accountable for assault.

text1: A lack of vaccination puts "weaker individuals" (immune deficient, and children too young to get vaccinated yet) at risk and can lead to their infection. Those who know that they suffer from a transmittable disease that can gravely endanger the lives of weaker individuals, and still refuse to be vaccinated, could be classified as assaulting those who are vulnerable.
text2: Not everyone believes that positive and negative moral obligations exist in equal weight (if positive obligations exist at all). "Thou shall not murder" is meaningfully different from "Thou shall feed all starving children."

text1: Injection by needle is not a necessary condition for receiving a vaccination.
text2: Pushing a needle into a person without their consent constitutes assault.

text1: Even if pushing a needle into a person without their consent does constitute assault, the social contract may suggest that individuals who are born into and live in a society are morally obligated to consent to its laws and customs.
text2: Pushing a needle into a person without their consent constitutes assault.

text1: While outlawing meat eating would contribute to slowing down the climate change, it would not stop it. Vaccination with high enough rate does prevent outbreaks completely and can even lead to disease elimination.
text2: It is still permissible to eat meat although farming is one of the leading drivers of climate change.

text1: Smoking is not allowed in public places, only in regulated areas. You could argue that non vaccinated people should therefore be confined to specific areas.
text2: Smoking is still allowed, although secondhand or 'passive' smoking poses a high health risk to society.

text1: You can identify someone smoking and avoid them pretty easily, you do not know if someone is vaccinated. If you would mark non vaccinated people, than it would be an equivalent.
text2: Smoking is still allowed, although secondhand or 'passive' smoking poses a high health risk to society.

text1: Individual liberty is not protected when behaviors have been proven to be risky to other people's life. For example, a person cannot drink while driving, or over-speed because it is considered a dangerous behavior.
text2: Individual liberty is protected in the case of many other individual choices that pose a greater health risk and cost for society, hence rendering vaccines mandatory is arbitrary and unwarranted.

text1: Individual liberty is not protected when behaviors have been proven to be risky to other people's life. For example, a person cannot drink while driving, or over-speed because it is considered a dangerous behavior.
text2: Smoking is allowed while second hand smoke still exists. Driving is on public spaces, while being vaccinated affects someones bodily autonomy. Smoking is a better comparison if someone can put themselves at risk.

text1: The Catholic Church issued a statement where they accepted this fact but still allowed believers to use such vaccines.
text2: Certain vaccines use DNA from aborted fetuses in production, which might be considered unethical by people holding pro-life religious beliefs.

text1: Religious beliefs are not receivable arguments when it comes to making decisions impacting the whole society, it can only have value inside a community made of people sharing the same beliefs. Therefore, since vaccinating children is a matter of national health, only rational, science based arguments should be accepted.
text2: Substances contained inside vaccines might be seen as unethical by individuals holding certain religious beliefs or ethical positions.

text1: The harm of a shot to the baby is too brief to matter, especially when weighed against the benefit of protecting them against diseases and infections.
text2: Many parents are distressed by the fact that shots make babies cry. Their wishes and decisions to avoid this should be respected.

text1: Taking a baby away from an abusive mother would make it cry but the act is still just. Therefore not all rules and procedures that make babies cry are wrong.
text2: Many parents are distressed by the fact that shots make babies cry. Their wishes and decisions to avoid this should be respected.

text1: A cry is only the manifestation of the disagreement from the baby about something. It is therefore unreliable due to the imprecision and the subjectivity of the information.
text2: Many parents are distressed by the fact that shots make babies cry. Their wishes and decisions to avoid this should be respected.

text1: Parents who do not have sufficient knowledge or expertise in health care are not capable of making an informed decision for their children's healthcare.
text2: It is a breach into the liberty of parents to choose the best healthcare for their children.

text1: Parents who do not have sufficient knowledge or expertise in health care are not capable of making an informed decision for their children's healthcare.
text2: Parents need to be provided with all information (pro's and con's) so they can make an informed decision.

text1: If the specific vaccine decreases the risk of death or other serious health impacts for a child whose parents oppose vaccination, compulsory vaccination might be seen as a way to defend the right to healthcare for the child (Bradley, 1999).
text2: The 'child' can make up their own mind when they are older and at the age of consent.

text1: The above claim in no way addresses the child's right to healthcare 'during childhood'. If parents refusing vaccine are denying their child's rights, it is not sufficient to say that the child will be able to reverse the decision as an adult (even assuming he/she survives that long). This is not the precedent set for dealing with other parental actions that endanger the child's life, i.e. child abuse.
text2: The 'child' can make up their own mind when they are older and at the age of consent.

text1: Belief systems are never sufficiently important to justify risking a child's life or those of other people.
text2: It is a breach into the liberty of parents to choose the best healthcare for their children.

text1: If the parents have liberty to choose the best health care, they also have to have liberty to choose the worst health care. Since the government does not allow parents to harm their children, which is breach of their liberty to do so, it should also not allow them to harm their children by mandating them to be vaccinated.
text2: It is a breach into the liberty of parents to choose the best healthcare for their children.

text1: For religions that do not permit injected vaccines, alternate forms of many vaccinations are available--e.g. the polio vaccine is given as an oral form in several countries.
text2: Many people object to getting vaccinated because it violates religious conventions.

text1: For religions that do not permit injected vaccines, alternate forms of many vaccinations are available--e.g. the polio vaccine is given as an oral form in several countries.
text2: Polio is the only routine childhood vaccine that is available in oral and injected forms. There is no oral form of vaccine for Measles, Mumps, Rubella, Hepatitis B, HIB, Diptheria, Pertussis, or Tetanus. There is no oral flu vaccine, although there is an intranasal one.

text1: Many people object to PE and forge a note from their Mom. There are few examples of religions objecting to vaccination. However individual preachers may lead their own flock according to personal interpretations or prejudices.
text2: Many people object to getting vaccinated because it violates religious conventions.

text1: Many people object to PE and forge a note from their Mom. There are few examples of religions objecting to vaccination. However individual preachers may lead their own flock according to personal interpretations or prejudices.
text2: Religion is inherently following doctrine. If this is from an individual, an organization, or a holy book, religion still should be respected.

text1: We already ban substances that cause harm to humans, which lessens liberty in exchange for societal benefits, as mandatory vaccination would.
text2: Mandatory vaccination is a breach into individual liberty.

text1: We already ban substances that cause harm to humans, which lessens liberty in exchange for societal benefits, as mandatory vaccination would.
text2: During alcohol prohibition in the US, it became apparent that the ban on alcohol caused more harm than alcohol itself. As a result, the constitutional amendment prohibiting alcohol was repealed. Using state violence in hopes of achieving societal benefits has a terrible track record.

text1: We already ban substances that cause harm to humans, which lessens liberty in exchange for societal benefits, as mandatory vaccination would.
text2: While we do ban harmful substances, in no other case - except for emergency situations - is a medical therapy mandated for the greater good.

text1: We already ban substances that cause harm to humans, which lessens liberty in exchange for societal benefits, as mandatory vaccination would.
text2: Banning something is totally different from forcing someone to take something against their will. They are not the same.

text1: We already ban substances that cause harm to humans, which lessens liberty in exchange for societal benefits, as mandatory vaccination would.
text2: There is nothing inherent about anti-vaxxers that suggests they must support the drug war.

text1: Outlawing a product (such as alcohol) may predictably result in a black market based on the profit motive of selling that product. It is unlikely that criminal gangs will form for the purpose of skirting vaccination laws.
text2: During alcohol prohibition in the US, it became apparent that the ban on alcohol caused more harm than alcohol itself. As a result, the constitutional amendment prohibiting alcohol was repealed. Using state violence in hopes of achieving societal benefits has a terrible track record.

text1: The parent resolution says nothing about using violence to enforce the mandate for vaccines.
text2: During alcohol prohibition in the US, it became apparent that the ban on alcohol caused more harm than alcohol itself. As a result, the constitutional amendment prohibiting alcohol was repealed. Using state violence in hopes of achieving societal benefits has a terrible track record.

text1: The government can pressure people into treatment, with people that have had drug abuse problems this seems to be effective
text2: While we do ban harmful substances, in no other case - except for emergency situations - is a medical therapy mandated for the greater good.

text1: Making any behavior mandatory, OR banning any behavior, are both limitations on individual liberty.
text2: Banning something is totally different from forcing someone to take something against their will. They are not the same.

text1: Individual liberties are generally accepted as being outside of the governments control or purview. Governments are obligated to care for the health and well being of it's citizenry. This puts vaccination into the area of civil liberty, or laws for the good of the community.
text2: Mandatory vaccination is a breach into individual liberty.

text1: We don't have individual liberty to neglect children. In a situation where a parent (without the approval of a doctor) has no good reason not to protect their children, it is not 'liberty' but just neglect.
text2: Mandatory vaccination is a breach into individual liberty.

text1: We don't have individual liberty to neglect children. In a situation where a parent (without the approval of a doctor) has no good reason not to protect their children, it is not 'liberty' but just neglect.
text2: Where it comes to medical treatment, individuals must have the right to not trust the government or medical experts. Non-treatment is not neglect, unless the treatment can be risk free. Treatment is always a choice to weight up the benefits with the risks. Death or injury in a forced treatment is not acceptable even in a very small chance.

text1: Becoming infected with a preventable disease, having chosen not to receive the vaccination, then infecting another person breaches that person's individual liberty.
text2: Mandatory vaccination is a breach into individual liberty.

text1: Becoming infected with a preventable disease, having chosen not to receive the vaccination, then infecting another person breaches that person's individual liberty.
text2: Not everyone believes that positive and negative moral obligations exist in equal weight (if positive obligations exist at all). "Thou shall not murder" is meaningfully different from "Thou shall feed all starving children."

text1: Individual liberty may be a necessary sacrifice depending on the severity of the risk to the public's health.
text2: Mandatory vaccination is a breach into individual liberty.

text2: Due to the scarcity of resources, seeking to eradicate any one disease might come at a loss to society. This would be the case if the ratio of benefits to cost for such mandatory immunisation campaign were lower than that for alternative measures that benefit public health.

text1: In a civilized society, the needs of the many should, at times when the impact is greatest, be above the needs of the few or individual. Eradicating or limiting a disease by use of vaccinations is for the greater good of society.
text2: It is the means of a 'few' immuno-compromised individuals that we are protecting. So our rights to bodily choice is affected by the few. Some immuno-compromised are still vaccinated. Only those who have anaphylaxis are fully exempt.

text1: In a civilized society, the needs of the many should, at times when the impact is greatest, be above the needs of the few or individual. Eradicating or limiting a disease by use of vaccinations is for the greater good of society.
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: There's a price to pay for living in a civilized society. You sacrifice certain individual freedoms for the benefits of teamwork and being in a social group. In this case, the sacrifice is only the freedom to be ignorant, which is not a high value form of individual liberty.
text2: "Ignorance" is not the freedom at stake here. It is the freedom of deciding what goes into your body. Ignorance simply means not knowing.

text1: Eradicating certain communicable, vaccine-preventable diseases (like polio & measles) worldwide requires that developed countries continue to maintain high rates of vaccination and immunity, even though individuals in those countries are at low risk of exposure to the disease.
text2: Eradication of any diseases is an arbitrary target that hasn't been agreed democratically.

text1: Eradicating certain communicable, vaccine-preventable diseases (like polio & measles) worldwide requires that developed countries continue to maintain high rates of vaccination and immunity, even though individuals in those countries are at low risk of exposure to the disease.
text2: Eradication of other non-contagious diseases such as tetanus cannot be attained via vaccination, since no herd immunity can be attained in this way.

text1: The erasure of human pain and suffering doesn't need political backing to be morally just.
text2: Eradication of any diseases is an arbitrary target that hasn't been agreed democratically.

text1: The erasure of human pain and suffering doesn't need political backing to be morally just.

text1: Seeking to eradicate one disease may strengthen healthcare infrastructure, as the Global Polio Eradication Initiative has done in developing countries. The resources poured into eradicating one disease, have resulted in improved access to healthcare for many conditions. (p. 2)
text2: Due to the scarcity of resources, seeking to eradicate any one disease might come at a loss to society. This would be the case if the ratio of benefits to cost for such mandatory immunisation campaign were lower than that for alternative measures that benefit public health.

text1: Strategies to eliminate certain diseases completely (like smallpox, polio and measles) may free up future resources, by saving the money that is currently spent annually on the burden of disease.
text2: Due to the scarcity of resources, seeking to eradicate any one disease might come at a loss to society. This would be the case if the ratio of benefits to cost for such mandatory immunisation campaign were lower than that for alternative measures that benefit public health.

text1: Immunocompromised people should not receive live vaccine, out of the concern that it will cause active diseases. They can still receive killed/inactivated vaccines, but are less likely to respond and gain immunity from them, because that's what immunocompromised means.
text2: It is the means of a 'few' immuno-compromised individuals that we are protecting. So our rights to bodily choice is affected by the few. Some immuno-compromised are still vaccinated. Only those who have anaphylaxis are fully exempt.

text1: Small pox has been eradicated primarily through a successful global vaccination program.WHO
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: Polio is very close to being eradicated by vaccines.
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: The aim of vaccines is to reduce the amount of a virus in circulation in society and thus reduce the amount of infection from that disease, not necessarily eradicate them.
text2: Vaccines have never actually completely eradicated a disease and likely never will. Even the definition of eradication allows for some cases.

text1: Protecting the liberty of individuals who do not want to vaccinate themselves (or their children) may conflict with protecting the liberty of other individuals who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons (e.g. immunodeficiency) to safely use public spaces due to the increased risk to their health.
text2: Immune suppressed individuals can be infected by individuals recently vaccinated for chickenpox (varicella), intranasal flu vaccine within one week, rotavirus, or Oral Polio Vaccine. As such, vaccinated children can endanger others as they can still carry diseases even though they do not show symptoms themselves.

text1: Protecting the liberty of individuals who do not want to vaccinate themselves (or their children) may conflict with protecting the liberty of other individuals who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons (e.g. immunodeficiency) to safely use public spaces due to the increased risk to their health.
text2: It cannot be easily generalised by how much the health risk for individuals who cannot be vaccinated would increase due to the presence of other voluntarily non-vaccinated people attending the same public spaces. Considering that vaccine-preventable diseases are far from being the most frequent causes of illness in our society, it could be argued that the health risk would only increase marginally.

text1: Protecting the liberty of individuals who do not want to vaccinate themselves (or their children) may conflict with protecting the liberty of other individuals who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons (e.g. immunodeficiency) to safely use public spaces due to the increased risk to their health.
text2: It is a false equivalence to compare liberty to not have foreign matter introduced to your body by force with the liberty to walk about in nature. The latter liberty is not restricted in this case by authority, but by nature itself.

text1: Protecting the liberty of individuals who do not want to vaccinate themselves (or their children) may conflict with protecting the liberty of other individuals who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons (e.g. immunodeficiency) to safely use public spaces due to the increased risk to their health.
text2: It is the responsibility of each of us to take care of our own health and well being. It's not one person's responsibility to look after the other, but those who suffer from health issues to look after themselves.

text1: Protecting the liberty of individuals who do not want to vaccinate themselves (or their children) may conflict with protecting the liberty of other individuals who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons (e.g. immunodeficiency) to safely use public spaces due to the increased risk to their health.
text2: Vulnerable children will be vulnerable to many diseases, not just ones for which vaccines exist. Vaccinating others is therefore not a viable method to manage their condition.

text1: Oral polio vaccine has not been routinely administered in the U.S. since 1997, when it switched to the injected (inactivated) form, which carries zero risk or infection to contacts of the vaccinated person.

As such, vaccinated children can endanger others as they can still carry diseases even though they do not show symptoms themselves.

text1: One has the liberty to not get vaccinated, but then one must accept the penalty. Our choices must carry consequences.
text2: Mandatory vaccination is a breach into individual liberty.

text1: Communicable diseases have no respect for international borders. Efforts to control or eradicate these illnesses must be based on worldwide disease burden, i.e. countries with low incidence of disease need to maintain high rates of vaccination until the disease is eradicated/ controlled everywhere.
text2: The beneficial impact of a mandatory immunisation campaign depends on country- and region-specific conditions, which make it hard or impossible to generally state that vaccines must be made mandatory everywhere.

text1: The number of lives that could be saved is clear from comparing incidence of disease in developed vs. underdeveloped countries.
text2: More complex statistical analysis techniques such as multivariate regression are required to establish the correlation between immunisation rates and incidence of disease. For this it is necessary to correct for differences in the general state of health among different countries and different periods, e.g. accounting for differences in the healthcare system, diet etc.

text1: The number of lives that could be saved is clear from comparing incidence of disease in developed vs. underdeveloped countries.
text2: Depending on the disease, high incidence of a diseases needs not mean high number of deaths, if a good healthcare service is available.

text1: Cases of paralytic polio in the US fell from 15,000 annually in 1955 (when the first vaccine was introduced) to 10 per year in the 1970s.
text2: More complex statistical analysis techniques such as multivariate regression are required to establish the correlation between immunisation rates and incidence of disease. For this it is necessary to correct for differences in the general state of health among different countries and different periods, e.g. accounting for differences in the healthcare system, diet etc.

text1: This statistical analysis would necessarily be based on historical data, and thus would never be entirely applicable to today's population. By this logic no new product should ever be introduced, nor any new treatment recommended.
text2: More complex statistical analysis techniques such as multivariate regression are required to establish the correlation between immunisation rates and incidence of disease. For this it is necessary to correct for differences in the general state of health among different countries and different periods, e.g. accounting for differences in the healthcare system, diet etc.

text1: This statistical analysis would necessarily be based on historical data, and thus would never be entirely applicable to today's population. By this logic no new product should ever be introduced, nor any new treatment recommended.
text2: By this argument it would also not be possible to demonstrate the effectiveness of vaccines, since it would be hard to argue that any observed correlation between the incidence in the disease and the immunisation coverage reflects a deeper deterministic link and is not simply spurious.

text1: In countries where there is not good access to health care, it is not only more expedient, but more humane, to provide vaccine and eliminate suffering and death from at least one disease.
text2: Depending on the disease, high incidence of a diseases needs not mean high number of deaths, if a good healthcare service is available.

text1: The administration of vaccines would reduce healthcare costs due to vaccine-preventable diseases complications and treatment.
text2: It would be expensive for countries to give every single person on the planet many vaccines.

text1: Oral polio vaccine has not been routinely administered in the U.S. since 1997, when it switched to the injected (inactivated) form, which carries zero risk or infection to contacts of the vaccinated person.
text2: Immune suppressed individuals can be infected by individuals recently vaccinated for chickenpox (varicella), intranasal flu vaccine within one week, rotavirus, or Oral Polio Vaccine. text1: This does not account for the fact that many more cases of polio have been avoided thanks to the vaccine itself.
text2: The circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus has been responsible for more cases of paralysis than the wild poliovirus in recent years.

text1: Vaccination schedules in several countries have replaced the use of oral vaccines (i.e. OPV, which could cause cVDPV) with safer ones (IPV), a trend that is considered positive by some.
text2: The circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) has the potential to cause health impacts similar to those of the polio virus itself, which has been the cause of multiple outbreaks in the past, and as recently as 2017 in Syria.

text1: Vaccine shedding is mainly a concern through fecal-oral contamination. With the example of circulating vaccine derived polio, the reason this virus mutated back to an infectious form was because the attenuated form was used in areas with low vaccination rates, allowing it to spread and mutate.
text2: The circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) has the potential to cause health impacts similar to those of the polio virus itself, which has been the cause of multiple outbreaks in the past, and as recently as 2017 in Syria.

text1: Vaccine shedding is only a concern for those with severely weakened immune systems.
text2: Vaccine shedding is a real concern.

text1: Most vaccines do not shed.
text2: Vaccine shedding is a real concern.

text1: There is almost no record of any substantial harm done to others (11 in 50 million for chickenpox, for example).
text2: Vaccine shedding is a real concern.

text1: Vaccine shedding is much higher with wild-type infection than with vaccinated individuals, and the wild-type pathogens are more likely to cause disease than the attenuated vaccine-type strains.
text2: Vaccine shedding is a real concern.

text1: Shedding of attenuated (weakened) virus may be beneficial, by passively immunizing the imunocompetent contacts of the vaccinated child. This is important in third-world countries, where the likelihood of wild-type disease in immunocompetent contacts is much higher than the likelihood of vaccine-type disease in immunosuppressed contacts.
text2: Vaccine shedding is a real concern.

text1: For some diseases, like polio, total eradication is within reach, which would justify the expenditure of public health dollars now, and save money in the future when, as with smallpox, there may be a day when vaccination is no longer needed
text2: Rendering vaccines mandatory does not necessarily represent a cost-effective way of improving public health in all countries.

text1: Review of vaccination strategies has demonstrated that the majority of universal vaccination programs are cost-saving from the perspective of society compared to no vaccination. Vaccination programs are among the rare health interventions that are cost-saving.
text2: Rendering vaccines mandatory does not necessarily represent a cost-effective way of improving public health in all countries.

text1: A different regimen of mandatory vaccinations can be somewhat tailored to individual countries. Should a malaria vaccine ever be developed, it may not be necessary in colder climes, for instance, though absolutely necessary equatorially.
text2: Rendering vaccines mandatory does not necessarily represent a cost-effective way of improving public health in all countries.

text1: We've never used the criteria of cost-effectiveness before in spending decisions, such as the disproportionate spending of taxpayers money each year into military and nuclear weapons, as well as atomic arms.
text2: Rendering vaccines mandatory does not necessarily represent a cost-effective way of improving public health in all countries.

text1: Diseases are a method of natural selection. Bypassing them via vaccination is of greater detriment to society due to the increase in hereditary weaknesses.
text2: Rendering vaccines mandatory does not necessarily represent a cost-effective way of improving public health in all countries.

text1: The link is to a study in mice, which tested effect of aluminum on cognitive function in the short term and found adverse effects from a dose of aluminum which, in humans, would be proportional to 10 to 15 times as much aluminum as contained in one dose of most vaccines.
text2: The most common adjuvant used in vaccines (i.e. Aluminium oxide hydroxide, Alhydrogel) might be neurotoxic even at low doses.

text1: The Vaccine Injury Compensation Program was made in the 1980's after a vaccine scare which has since been discredited. The website even says people are paid even when there is no finding of causality.
text2: A lot of money has been payed due to vaccine injuries.

text1: The Vaccine Injury Compensation Program was made in the 1980's after a vaccine scare which has since been discredited. The website even says people are paid even when there is no finding of causality.
text2: The VICP is managed by the DOJ. The VICP mandate states that it provides "...compensation for vaccine injury-related medical and rehabilitative expenses..." The standard by the DOJ is clear. Money is paid when they believe an injury caused by a vaccine occurred, which is not easy. Less than 10% of people who file a claim with the VICP are adjudged to be eligible for compensation. 30% are settled prior to Judgment and the remaining 60% are either withdrawn or deemed not eligible.
